p: Enzymatic hydrolysis is the most common process for the preparation of antioxidant peptides, which have been tested in the form of crude hydrolysates or purified peptides. It was reported that crude hydrolysates from the chlorophytes, Chlorella pyrenoidosa [ 201], Chlorella ellipsiodea, and Tetraselmis suecica [ 202], showed strong antioxidant activity in vitro and on skin fibroblasts. The purified peptides, Val-Glu-Cys-Tyr-Gly-Pro-Asn-Arg-Pro-Glu-Phe and Leu-Asn-Gly-Asp-Val-Trp, from the pepsin hydrolysate of Chlorella vulgaris and Chlorella ellipsiodea, respectively, had strong superoxide and DPPH radical scavenging activities [ 203, 204]. Similarly, two bioactive peptides, Pro-Gly-Trp-Asn-Gln-Trp-Phe-Leu and Val-Glu-Val-Leu-Pro-Pro-Ala-Glu-Leu, isolated from papain hydrolysate of Navicula incerta, demonstrated potent antioxidant properties in HepG2/CYP2E1 cells [ 205].
